Prisons want to keep in touch with their gay communities by not being allowed to read these papers.
So we're going to be involved in a suit probably,
and we feel lucky, the Congressional Correctional Act Institute in Kentucky,
and maybe one here at the Lompoc Prison, and possibly one down in Texas as well.
And then the last thing that I want to talk about is the rights of gay students.
I went to, well, I went to several undergraduate schools, but I graduated from Michigan State University,
which is where I first got involved in gay political causes.
And as a student, I brought a suit against the university for refusing to allow us to place a banner on the two official posts, shall we say, of the university where you can announce events.
And Michigan State University is on a main thoroughfare with 40,000 cars a day past students' intersections.
We wanted to put a banner that said Gay Pride Week, and the administration wouldn't let us.
So we filed an action against the university.
We didn't win, but it was probably because we weren't adequately prepared, because we found out from sort of some of our sources,
post-administration, that they had been warned by their lawyers not to do that again next year, because they were probably in some pretty serious trouble.
And so the next year, we made an application to put up the banner, and we ended up without any problems.
Now, this same school, sitting in a city that has an anti-discrimination ordinance, which I helped lobby for in 1971,
Last year they allowed that gay students be kicked out of fraternities simply because they were gay.
So even though you have an anti-discrimination ordinance, it's not going to be worth a whole lot and it's not enforced.
So there are continuing problems going on.
We found that there's another school called Andrews College which is trying to kick out two students because they alleged they were gay.

There's a private college in the suburbs of Chicago that once ran a bachelor's degree to a student who's completed all of his coursework and said this person's gay and doesn't meet the criminal character requirements of our schools and he can't handle his degree.

We find that the University of Arkansas in Batesville, the school has official, grant official university recognition to the student organization there, but they won't grant them any office space or any funding or any of the benefits that might go along with official recognition.
There's two cases going on in Texas right now involving the rights of students to get recognition at their campus.
And my last big gay rights case before I came to the West Coast involved the lawsuit against Georgetown University in Washington, D.C.
because they would not grant recognition to the undergraduate and to the law school gay student organizations.
So there are still a lot of lawsuits involved with students, as well as many other areas that are important.
We can become complacent here in California. It doesn't have a sodomy statute anymore.
We have a lot of protections. People to a great extent are maybe a lot more relaxed.
They're used to hearing about seeing a gay community as sort of this old hat.
But in most parts of the country, there's still a lot of problems, and that's what National Gay Rights Advocates is all about, is writing these new laws about the rest of the country.
Is Gay Rights Advocates taking on any cases involving gay youth and their rights to their sexuality that have not been treated?
Because that seems to be something in California that is still an issue, and it's very hard to consider.
Yeah, there's a lot of problems in that area.
We have not taken on any cases involving that issue.
I can't say we've been presented with any.
What we do in determining what cases to take is we basically wait for people to come to us,
which is not much of a problem.
I get calls every day.
If a day doesn't go by, they don't get at least one call,
so I'm not concerned about some kind of discrimination or adverse action.
But that particular issue hasn't reached us yet.
We haven't had any complaints in a long
That is a way of certainly discriminating against gay people without being so forthright as saying that we're not going to allow two gay people to live together.
The history of that kind of legislation I'm not so sure was necessarily anti-gay but was intended to keep noise down and to protect sort of family type environments.
some of you guys like that it's very subtle
some states like virginia
